NATION.NAME: Anjo
NATION.FULLNAME: The Delegate of TSP 🍰 of Anjo
NATION.ANIMALTRAIT: frolics freely in the nation's many lush forests
NATION.CRIME: Crime, especially youth-related, is totally unknown.
NATION.GOVTDESC: The medium-sized, outspoken government juggles the competing demands of Education, Spirituality, and Welfare. It meets to discuss matters of state in the capital city of Tepertopia.
NATION.INDUSTRYDESC: The anjo economy, worth 161 trillion drama llamas a year, is led by the Book Publishing industry, with major contributions from Tourism, Retail, and Soda Sales. Average income is 48,812 drama llamas, and evenly distributed, with the richest citizens earning only 3.4 times as much as the poorest.

POLICY.NAME: Marriage Equality
POLICY.DESC: Citizens of the same sex may marry.

POLICY.NAME: Sex Education
POLICY.DESC: School-age children receive mandatory sex education.

POLICY.NAME: Capitalism
POLICY.DESC: Private industry is permitted within a market-based economy.

LEGISLATION.LAW: the government is promoting multicultural values with the new 'Just Be Nice, OK?' initiative
the government has spent days debating the merits of a petition calling for a ban on sporks
museums have more touchscreens on display than artifacts
scientists recently cloned the long-extinct feather-bellied housecat

ISSUESUMMARY.ISSUE: You Donâ€™t Have to Be Mad to Kill People... But It Helps

ISSUE.TITLE: Weâ€™re Dying for Your Business
ISSUE.TEXT: A recent exposÃ© of the death care industry revealed that funeral costs are leaving some families dead broke. The reason for the price increases is thought to be because while population growth continues to rise, funeral parlour growth has stopped cold, resulting in shocking cases of price gouging. Demand for last rites has become so high that families sometimes have to pawn all of the deceasedâ€™s possessions just to afford a simple burial.
ISSUE.AUTHOR: pigeontree
ISSUE.OPTION: â€œDying is not something we have a choice in,â€ weeps a sombre woman dressed all in black. â€œThe tragic death of a loved one followed by an astronomical bill landing on our doorsteps can put familiesâ€™ finances in a death spiral. I urge you, anjoâ€™s brain, to scrap death charges altogether and provide state-funded funerals for everyone. That way families wonâ€™t have to mourn their bank accounts as well as their loved ones.â€

â€œYes, and do you know why thereâ€™s a shortage of funeral services, hmmm?â€ quietly seethes funeral director Igor Fronkensteen, while dragging a lumpy burlap sack behind him. â€œBurial plot land costs...they are rising, yes? The price of insuring a hearse these days is, how do you say, absolutely ludicrous, yes? And the restrictive laws on â€˜adequate refrigerationâ€™ and â€˜treating the dead with dignityâ€™ all are running our margins and my salary down! You want more funeral services at a cheaper price, you should ease up on the bureaucracy, yes?â€

â€œFuneral services? What a waste of money,â€ scoffs obscure thinker Siko Sulu, who has yet to sell any copies of her book Rich Dead, Poor Dead. â€œWhatâ€™s the point in some drawn-out shebang for someone whoâ€™s not even going to be around to see it? Do away with funerals altogether. That way we can cremate everyone and harvest their bodies for phosphorus!â€

ISSUE.TITLE: Breath of the Wild
ISSUE.TEXT: Scientists have successfully revived the long-extinct feather-bellied housecat to the point where a population of the creatures can be sustained in the wild. The nationâ€™s leading wildlife experts and housecat enthusiasts have offered their suggestions on how Anjo should handle these animals.
ISSUE.AUTHOR: nation_of_quebec
ISSUE.OPTION: â€œWe canâ€™t upset the balance of nature!â€ proclaims Mipha Hunt, Chief Veterinarian at a national park in Anjo, while feeding the fish in your office. â€œThese animals havenâ€™t been around for more than a hundred years. Who knows how theyâ€™ll react to their new surroundings? It could cause a total shift in the food-chain and the entire ecosystem. We should maintain their population in controlled environments â€” like preserves, research centers and zoos.â€

â€œI know how to deal with this,â€ states Revali Pond, a renowned hunter, who deftly grabs one of the office fish and nails it to the wall. â€œIf youâ€™re worried that too many of these animals would disrupt the ecosystem, then allow us hunters to take care of the problem. It would be a phenomenal experience to track down creatures that nobody has seen in generations and tourists would flock to Anjo for the thrill of the hunt. All in the name of the balance of nature, of course!â€

â€œInstead of tampering with nature, why not just let it be?â€ proposes Daruk Wickremesinghe, an animal rights activist. â€œWe have proved that we have the power to bring these species back to life, but now they need to be left alone in peace. Release these animals into the wild and let Mother Nature take her course. Be a friend of the environment, not the master of it.â€

â€œThese animals should be used for the benefit of all anjos,â€ asserts farmer Urbosa Dixon, as he herds a flock of sheep around your office. â€œWhat a waste it would be to release them into the wild â€” they belong on farms! Imagine all that they could do for us, and the gourmet foods that we could make with their juicy, succulent meat!â€

ISSUE.TITLE: Corruption in the Lobby
ISSUE.TEXT: After the passage of a bill giving billions of drama llamas to â€œany oil company with two â€˜xâ€™s in its nameâ€, there was much discussion over the influence that corporate lobbies have over the government and whether it was getting out of hand - until an all-waves radio and TV broadcast suggested citizens go have a coffee at Starbucks instead.
ISSUE.AUTHOR: the_seniors_of_zion
ISSUE.OPTION: â€œIt disgusts me how much this government is eating out of the hands of corporations,â€ says Kasie Wilk, an anti-corporate activist. â€œA governmentâ€™s first priority is supposed to be its people! Anjo! Not some faceless company interested in nothing but money! The right to petition is for individual citizens, not for multinational companies that answer to no one.â€

â€œThereâ€™s no need to get excited, weâ€™ve got everyoneâ€™s best interests at heart,â€ replies Iris Meyer, a corporate lobbyist. â€œYes, individuals have the right to make their opinions known to the government, but so too do groups of individuals. And thatâ€™s all a corporation is: a group of individuals wanting to contribute. By helping corporations, the government helps the country. Unemployment goes down, the economy goes up, and everyoneâ€™s favourite products become more readily available. In fact, if corporations were already part of the political process we could do so much more! I propose that companies be allowed to run for office.â€

â€œOver my dead body they will,â€ says Miles Sullivan, a civil servant. â€œThe problem with lobbying is that itâ€™s so easily abused. There are too many opinionated idiots out there prepared to rally around some obnoxious or silly cause. Last week the parliament reviewed a petition from thousands of citizens complaining about birds being too noisy! I mean, really! Weâ€™d be better off ignoring lobbyists altogether and trusting in your own sagacity, esteemed leader.â€

ISSUE.TITLE: You Donâ€™t Have to Be Mad to Kill People... But It Helps
ISSUE.TEXT: Anjo was in shock after a recent mass murder, and shocked again when the suspect pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, after a privately employed psychiatrist convinced the courts that he had no ability to tell right from wrong. anjos are deeply divided over the notion of insanity pleas, and many angry citizens are demanding that you step in.
ISSUE.AUTHOR: liberamare
ISSUE.OPTION: â€œThe only thing thatâ€™s insane is that youâ€™re actually considering allowing this!â€ cries a parent of one of the victims of the attack. â€œWhether or not this man is insane doesnâ€™t change the fact that my son is gone! This... murderer could have easily accessed psychiatric help and must take responsibility for his actions. He should face a proper jail sentence in a proper jail. All these insanity pleas do is give criminals an opportunity to abuse the system. We must show the scum of Anjo that they canâ€™t hide behind so-called â€˜pleasâ€™! Justice must prevail!â€

â€œActually, it is very difficult for the mentally ill to get the help they need in Anjo,â€ reminds the suspectâ€™s attorney after receiving a death glare from the parent. â€œIt is not their fault that theyâ€™re suffering and any psychiatrist worth their degree would agree that many donâ€™t have the mental capacity to determine right from wrong. We should be sending these people to mental institutions where they can be healed, not overcrowded prisons!â€

â€œThe solution to everything is a compromise,â€ declares one of your staffers, who claims that working for you has caused him to go insane. â€œRequire everyone accused of a crime to go through vigorous mental health testing to see if they are insane or not. This way, experts decide whether or not someone is insane at the beginning of a trial, leaving little room for errors.â€

ISSUE.TITLE: Fair to Say...?
ISSUE.TEXT: At last yearâ€™s World Fair many said that Anjoâ€™s exhibition pavilion was â€œokay, considering,â€ and â€œnot bad, for a nation on a tight budget.â€ This year, national organizers want to make your expo presence bigger, better, and more impressive than ever before.
ISSUE.AUTHOR: unibot_iii
ISSUE.OPTION: â€œWe need more shiny stuff! We need lasers, and twenty-foot-tall robots!â€ squeaks General Lisa Honda, hoverboarding excitedly round you in a wide circle. â€œLetâ€™s show off our tech to the rest of the world! We need flying cars and... and... cyberhousecats! Yes, a cyberhousecat, with a frickinâ€™ laser beam on its head!â€

â€œMy, how gauche!â€ sneers Martina Amis, an esteemed novelist. â€œCulture is the lifeblood of Anjo. We should create a gallery-slash-library to celebrate Anjoâ€™s arts and literature abroad. Nothing less could represent our brilliance.â€

â€œGive the fair-goers what they want! FOOOOOOOOD!â€ yells Adam Richbloke, a generously proportioned foodie holding a generous portion of battered chicken chunks. â€œVisitors to the fair arenâ€™t going to visit every tent; you know how many nations there are in the world now? But everyone has gotta eat! Chocolate doughnut lasagna, deep-fried pancake soups and orange truffle crabcakes with butter, pork and loads of sweet custard. Hmm, hmmm, hmmm, looks like everyone will be stopping by the Anjo pavilion!â€

â€œI smell economic opportunity,â€ says your Commerce Minister Ronald Dunn. â€œWe should showcase what a great place for investors we are, emphasising our flexible taxation arrangements for valued corporate investors and our latest moves to stamp out the unions. We should literally get on our knees, and beg the biggest businesses to bring jobs and prosperity to Anjo.â€
